questions.question_text: Which link in the web interface enables a security administrator to view the Security policy rules that match new application signatures?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct: https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-2/pan-os-admin/app-id/manage-new-app-ids-introduced-in-content-releases/review-new-app-id-impact-on-existing-policy-rules

Selected Answer: D
D it's correct, because 203.0.113.0/24 it's a reserved/special use address (TEST-NET-3. RFC 5737) so it can't stay in an outside zone.
D it's correct, because 203.0.113.0/24 it's a reserved/special use address (TEST-NET-3. RFC 5737) so it can't stay in an outside zone.
egress-outsid. source and destination zone possuem any + any aplication e application-default service, action allow. Então é "D"

Selected Answer: D
it's about ALL the traffic, so D is the correct answer

Selected Answer: D
The only option that matches "ALL" FTP traffic from Inside to Outside

Can someone explain why it is not D? 
If it say "any" FTP traffic wouldnt it have to be D since C would only match FTP traffic destined to that specific IP. Is that not correct?

comments.content: Correction, it says "ALL" FTP traffic. Wouldn't D be the first policy that allows "ALL" FTP traffic?
D it's correct, because 203.0.113.0/24 it's a reserved/special use address (TEST-NET-3. RFC 5737) so it can't stay in an outside zone.
Yup, the question doesn't ask about dst IP so I think C is correct.
But it does say "Match ALL ftp traffic" (not "any") which the Inside-portal would not match all the ftp traffic, just the FTP traffic destined to that specific IP.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
I mean, technically inside-portal would match any FTP traffic first to the outside zone, even if the destination address is defined.

questions.question_text:
Based on the shown security policy, which Security policy rule would match all FTP traffic from the inside zone to the outside zone?
//IMG//

discussion.content: The question says in progress changes.. changes are in the candidate config, they become part of the running-config after commit. Answer is B

Selected Answer: B
Answer B is Correct, Candidate

comments.content:
The question clearly states that: "... in-progress configuration" which is candidate that must be committed to be part of the running configuration. More details on the study guide Page 49 -50
https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/content/dam/pan/en_US/assets/pdf/datasheets/education/pcnsa-study-guide-latest.pdf

discussion.content: C is the correct. Running-configuration must be in-progress. Candidate configuration waits for a commit to be in-progress

questions.question_text: Which type of firewall configuration contains in-progress configuration changes?

discussion.content: Basically all IPv4 based: No point of having an IP if you don't have a netmask to determine network. Also no point to have an IP if there is no gateway to get out to the internet

questions.question_text: Which three configuration settings are required on a Palo Alto Network firewall management interface? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Tags. All Tags. Are specific to the creation of Policy. They have several purposes, apply to any object, can be defined and so forth. I am uncertain as to whether any action subsequent to their application is automated or not. The only thing I'm clear on is, they are Security Policy related, or to it's creation, whether automated or not.

Selected Answer: B
B is the correct answer

questions.question_text: What is an advantage for using application tags?

choices.D: They help with the design of IP address allocations in DHCP.
choices.C: They help with the creation of interfaces.
choices.B: They help content updates automate policy updates.
choices.A: They are helpful during the creation of new zones.
